newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Quality makes Pick a "buy"-OTP Securities.
newsitem.headline: Quality makes Pick a "buy"-OTP Securities.

text.p: An analyst report recommended Hungary's leading meat processor company Pick as both a short- and long-term buy despite forecasts of slower sales growth than other companies on the Budapest Stock Exchange (BSE).
"Pick is a mature company and is unlikely to experience high growth," OTP Securities, part of the OTP banking group, said in its latest report.
"At the same time it would be wrong to regard the high level of development as a negative factor."
Since acquiring its largest competitor Herz in 1994, Pick has seized more than 90 percent of the Hungarian high-quality salami market, OTP Securities analyst Andras Szalkai said.
But confidence in Pick is also founded on its success in Western markets, which other companies are unable to penetrate, he added.
"Pick alone accounts for one-third of all Hungarian meat exports," Szalkai said. "Pick's largest export market is Germany, a traditionally demanding market."
Szalkai said the 128-year-old company's finances were stable and predicted sales slightly higher than inflation over the coming years, helped by an expected increase in Hungarians' purchasing power.
He forecast price/earnings ratios of 10.52 and 8.94 for 1997 and 1998 results, respectively and expected the company to campaign more aggressively to increase sales to Eastern Europe.

In the short-term said Pick will benefit from the BSE's continued good performance, he said, while he projected 1996 pre-tax profit and net sales figures six to seven percent above the company's targets of 2.2 billion and 25.6 billion forints respectively.
"Our recommendation is for the short-term buy (and) we rate Pick a long-term buy due to its steady growth prospects," the report said.
